1790.note: First U.S. Census with basic racial categories: Free White, Other Free Persons, Slaves. Native Americans not systematically counted unless taxed.

1800.note: Same racial categories as 1790. Continued exclusion of untaxed Native Americans.

1810.note: Maintained racial classification from prior censuses. Still no enumeration of untaxed Native Americans.

1820.note: Added age and occupational distinctions but race categories remained basic: White, Free Colored, Slaves.

1830.note: Race categories unchanged. Some improvements in enumeration methodology.

1840.note: Increased questions on disabilities and occupation; racial categories still limited.

1850.note: Expanded racial categories include White, Black (free and slave), Biracial people. Native American populations largely excluded unless in settled communities.

1860.note: Similar racial categories to 1850. Intensified enumeration challenges due to pre-Civil War tensions.

1870.note: First post-emancipation census. Categories: White, Black, Biracial people, Chinese, Indian. Significant enumeration challenges in post-Civil War South.

1880.note: Continued use of racial categories: White, Black, Mulatto, Chinese, and Indian. 'Mulatto' was used inconsistently. Enumerators often made subjective judgments on race. Included more detailed socio-economic questions, but racial data remained constrained by 19th-century biases. Alaska Territory used different census questionnaires than the contiguous US.

1890.note: Peak 19th-century racial classification complexity. Categories included White, Black, Biracial people, Quadroon, Octoroon, Chinese, Japanese, Indian. Mixed-race classifications problematic by modern standards. Alaska Territory used different census questionnaires than the contiguous US.

1900.note: Simplified racial categories: White, Black, Chinese, Japanese, Indian. Beginning of more systematic enumeration of Asian populations. Alaska Territory used different census questionnaires than the contiguous US while Hawaii Territory used a different racial classifcation system

1910.note: Refined Asian classifications (e.g., Filipino, Hindu). Continued detailed tracking of Black and mixed-race individuals. Alaska Territory used different census questionnaires than the contiguous US while Hawaii Territory used a different racial classifcation system.

1920.note: Focus on immigrant populations. Race classifications largely unchanged but included nativity and mother tongue. Alaska Territory used different census questionnaires than the contiguous US while Hawaii Territory used a different racial classifcation system.

1930.note: Added Mexican as a racial category (later reclassified). Limited recognition of racial diversity within broad categories. Alaska Territory used different census questionnaires than the contiguous US while Hawaii Territory used a different racial classifcation system.

1940.note: First census with statistical sampling for detailed racial characteristics. Mexican reclassified as White unless obviously Indian or other non-White race. Alaska Territory used different census questionnaires than the contiguous US while Hawaii Territory used a different racial classifcation system.

1950.note: Enhanced racial classification with 20% sample. Improved Asian subcategory recognition but limited Latino/Hispanic identification. Alaska Territory used different census questionnaires than the contiguous US while Hawaii Territory used a different racial classifcation system.

1960.note: First census allowing self-identification of race. Continued sampling for detailed racial data. Beginning recognition of need for Hispanic/Latino ethnic category separate from race.

1970.note: Major methodological improvement in racial classification accuracy.

1980.note: Introduction of Hispanic origin question separate from race. Significant improvement in Latino/Hispanic population measurement.

1990.note: Expanded racial categories and improved Hispanic classification. Beginning awareness of multiracial identity issues.

2000.note: First census allowing respondents to identify with more than one race. Major step toward inclusive racial identity representation.
